revision.text:
[[File:A 2018 photo of Dr. Alan Marshall from an NZZ (Swiss newspaper) article on future cities.jpg|alt=Alan Marshall as he appears in a 2018 article about future cities published in the Swiss newspaper 'NZZ am Sonntag'|thumb|Alan Marshall in 2018 as shown in Swiss newspaper [https://nzzas.nzz.ch/hintergrund/alle-macht-den-staedten-ld.1364863 NZZ am Sonntag]|191x191px]]
'''Alan Marshall''' is a [[New Zealand]] author, artist and scholar working within the discipline of [[environmental studies]]. He is noted as a key scholar in [[environmental ethics|environmental philosophy]]<ref>Oliphant, J. ''et al.''(2011) AQA Religious Ethics for AS and A2, Routledge,978-0-203-83021-5: pp222.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://knowledge.sagepub.com/abstract/greenethics/n102.xml|title=Green Philosophy: an A to Z Guide|author=Newman, J.|first=|date=|year=2011|website=|publisher=Sage|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and for inventing the 'Literary Method of Urban Design'<ref>Marshall, A. (2018) 'The Fantasy Method of Urban Design', ''Diseña 12'', February 2018 issue -- available in Spanish and English via [http://ojs.uc.cl/index.php/Disena/article/view/45 ''Diseña''.]</ref>. For his research on these topics, the [[University of Wollongong]] awarded Marshall a doctorate and ''National Geographic'' assigned him as an explorer. Marshall has undertaken projects within institutes all around Europe and in the Asia-Pacific region. For example, he's held fellowships at [http://www.ifz.at/ias/IAS-STS/Fellows-and-Alumni/Alumni/Alan-Marshall IAS-STS] (Austria), the [[N. I. Lobachevsky State University of Nizhny Novgorod|State University of Nizhny Novgorod]] (Russia), [[University of Prešov|Prešov Universit]]<nowiki/>y & [[Pavol Jozef Šafárik University|UPJŠ]] (Slovakia), [[Masaryk University]] (Czech Republic), [[Khalifa University|KUSTAR]] (Abu Dhabi), [[Nirex|Nirex UK]] (Great Britain), [[Curtin University|Curtin University of Technology]] (Australia), and [[Mahidol University]] (Thailand).
==Major projects== In the 1990s Alan Marshall developed a [[postmodern]] version of the Human–Nature relationship,<ref>Marshall, A (1998) 'A Postmodern Natural History of the World, Studies in the History and Philosophy of Science', Part C, Vol. 34 Part C, No 1, 137-164</ref> one that throws into doubt the very concepts of 'Humanity' and 'Nature'.<ref>Marshall, A (2002) [https://www.worldscientific.com/worldscibooks/10.1142/p268 'The Unity of Nature: Wholeness and Disintegration in Ecology and Science'], Imperial College Press/World Scientific: London & Singapore.</ref>  Marshall's approach is heavily influenced by the science of [[ecology]] but has been criticized as privileging one school of ecology, i.e., '[[community ecology]]', over others such as [[systems ecology]] and the ecology of [[Gaia hypothesis|Gaia]].<ref>de Laplante, K. (2004) Environmental Alchemy: How to turn Ecological Science into Ecological Philosophy, Environmental Ethics, Vol 26, Winter Issue.</ref> His book ''The Unity of Nature''<ref>Alan Marshall (2002) ''[https://www.worldscientific.com/worldscibooks/10.1142/p268 The Unity of Nature]'', Imperial College Press/World Scientific: London & Singapore.</ref> is one of the fiercest critiques of [[Systems theory|Systems Theory]] in general, and [[Gaia hypothesis|Gaia Theory]] and [[Chaos theory|Chaos Theory]] in particular.
In 2006, Alan Marshall founded The [[appropedia:Ecomimicry|Ecomimicry]] Project which tries to meld ecology with Green [[innovation]], sustainable art, and the ethics of [[environmentalism]].<ref>See, for instance: A. Marshall (2007) ‘The Theory and Practice of Ecomimicry’, ''Sustaining Gondwana Working Paper Series'', Issue 3, publlished by Curtin University of Technology: Perth, or A. Marshall (2009) ''‘Wild Design: The Ecomimicry Project’'', published by North Atlantic Books: Berkeley.</ref>
Examples of designs that emerged from this project include:
* a Hemp Sail Battle Cruiser for the Royal Australian Navy (in which a navy ship had its engines 'designed-out' and in their stead it is powered by [[Sail|sails]] made from eco-friendly [[hemp]]) * a [[manure]]-powered swimming pool heating system (in which a luxury pool is heated by the composted [[Feces|body waste]] of the swimmers) * a hairy-roofed [[Carpathian Mountains|Carpathian mountain]] village where the architecture is adorned with an engineered protective material that mimics the fur of local [[Brown bear|brown bears.]]
These designs were compiled into Marshall's ''[https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/107954/wild-design-by-alan-marshall/ Wild Design]'' book and then praised by the Australian art & design media.<ref>Downton, P. (2009) Review of Wild Design, Artlink, Vol. 29, No. 4.</ref><ref>Wakely, M (2009) [http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/archived/bydesign/design-inspired-by-nature/3159490 Design Inspired By Nature], ABC Radio National's ''By Design'' program.</ref>
''<nowiki/><nowiki/><nowiki/><nowiki/><nowiki/><nowiki/><nowiki/><nowiki/><nowiki/><nowiki/><nowiki/>''
In January 2013, Marshall started the '[http://www.ecotopia2121.com/#!project-cities/c66t Ecotopia 2121]' project; which (as noted by ''CNN''<ref>CNN (2017) [https://edition.cnn.com/style/article/utopian-cities/index.html Utopian cities of the future re-imagine life on Earth], CNN Style/Architecture, January 2017</ref>'', Vanity Fair''<ref>D'Alessio, O. (2018) [https://www.vanityfair.it/viaggi-traveller/notizie-viaggio/2018/04/04/abbiamo-un-sogno-una-citta-dove-si-vive-pace 'Abbiamo un sogno, una città dove si vive in pace]' Vanity Fair Italia, April 2018. </ref> and ''The Independent''<ref>Blair, O. (2017) 'What will London and LA will look like in 2121?', ''The Independent'', Jan 19th, 2017.</ref>) explores 'graphic future scenarios' of 100 'super-ecofriendly' cities across the world. In 2015, the master-class part of this project conducted at Mahidol University was awarded the 2015 [[Kenneth Roemer|Kenneth M. Roemer]] Innovative Course Design Award by the [[Society for Utopian Studies]]. ''Ecotopia 2121'', the book of the project written and illustrated by Marshall, has attracted broad critical acclaim.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.euroscientist.com/journeys-towards-ecotopia-2121/|title=Journeys Toward Ecotopia 2121|last=EuroScientist|first=Science in Society|date=27 June 2016|work=EuroScientist|access-date=10 January 2017|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/WEFvideo/videos/10154168961996479/?pnref=story|title=Visions of Our Future Cities|last=World Economic Forum|first=WEF Agenda|date=2017-02-10|website=World Economic Forum|dead-url=|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref><ref>Loewe, E. (2018) This Is How Cities Of The Future May Deal With Climate Change, [https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/ecotopia-2121 MindBodyGreen], Feb.13th, 2018.</ref> The ''Times Higher Education'' review of ''Ecotopia 2121'' stated "very few academics ever produce anything as stunning and imaginative as this"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dorling|first=Danny|date=November 2016|title=Review of 'Ecotopia 2121: Visions of Our Future Green Utopia'|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/books/review-ecotopia-2121-alan-marshall-arcade|journal=Times Higher Education|volume=Nov 24th, 2016|pages=|via=}}</ref>, whilst the ''Daily Mail''<ref>Dean, Sarah (2018) [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5316713/Is-world-look-2121.html Is this how the world will look like in 2121?] ''[[Daily Mail]]'', 27th January 2018.</ref>, ''National Geographic''<ref>{{cite journal|last=Strochlic|first=N.|date=|year=2018|title=Here’s What Our Cities Could Look Like in 2121|url=|journal=National Geographic|volume=Vol. 233|issue=2|pages=|via=}}</ref> ''Al Jazeera''<ref>Al Jazeera (2018) [http://midan.aljazeera.net/miscellaneous/2018/5/16/%D8%B3%D8%AA-%D9%85%D8%AF%D9%86-%D9%81%D8%A7%D8%B6%D9%84%D8%A9-%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%AF%D9%83-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%AA%D8%AE%D9%8A%D9%84-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%A9-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8% A 'Utopian Cities' project helps to imagine a global environmental future], ''Al Jazeera,'' Doha, May 2018 (in Arabic).</ref>, ''Forbes''<ref>Forbes (2017) 'Urban Strategies: Aus Alt Mach Neu' in ''Forbes (Austria)'' November 2017 issue (in German).</ref> and ''Publishers Weekly''<ref>{{Cite journal|first=|date=|title=Review of 'Ecotopia 2121'|url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-62872-600-8|journal=Publishers Weekly|volume=Earth Day 2017|pages=|via=}}</ref> declared it 'visionary', 'thought-provoking' and 'curious and creative'. ''Ecotopia 2121'' was put on [[Resurgence & Ecologist|Resurgence and Ecologist]] magazine's Book of the Year list<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.resurgence.org/magazine/article4805-our-books-of-the-year.html|title=Resurgence • Article - Our Books of the Year|website=www.resurgence.org|language=en|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref>, won a Silver Medal at the 2017 Nautilus Book Awards and placed 1st in the 'Future Forecasts' category of the 2016 Green Book Festival, whilst the 'London 2121' cityscape from the book was chosen by the [[Museum of London]] to be displayed within their 2018 London Visions exhibition<ref>Aravani, F. (2018) London Visions: what does your future London look like?, Museum of London, Jan 17th 2018.</ref>. A reviewer in ''Strange Horizons''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://strangehorizons.com/|title=Strange Horizons: A Magazine of Speculative Fiction|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, in contrast, indicated that ''Ecotopia'' ''2121'' was 'offensive fluff' without ''<nowiki/>'''seriousness' and warned people 'not to read it under any circumstance'.
''<nowiki/>''
Marshall is also widely referred to as a critic of the car industry<ref>Marshall, A. (2015) 'Ecotopia 2121: Car-free Cities of the 22nd Century', ''Environment and Natural Resources Journal''. Vol 13, No.1,pp.28-38 </ref>, of the [[nuclear industry]]<ref>See, for example: A. Marshall (2005) 'The Social and Ethical Aspects of Nuclear Waste', ''[http://www.scimagojr.com/journalsearch.php?q=20362&tip=sid Electronic Green Journal]'', Issue 21, (Earth Day Issue); or A. Marshall (2005) ‘Questioning the Motivations for International Repositories for Nuclear Waste, ''[[Global Environmental Politics]]'', Vol. 5, No. 2, May 2005, pp. 1-7; or A. Marshall (2006) ''Dangerous Dawn: The New Nuclear Age,'' BNI/FoE: Melbourne, or A. Marshall (2008) 'Leaving Messages about Our Radioactive Waste for Future Generations', in A. P Latiffer, ed, ''[https://www.novapublishers.com/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=6699 Nuclear Waste Research]'', Nova Publishers, pp37-46.</ref> and of space exploration.<ref>See, for example: A. Marshall (2000) ‘The Search for Extraterrestrial Us: the Biases of SETI’, ''Australasian Science'', Vol. 21, No 3, April issue, pp36-37; and A. Marshall (1995) ‘Development and imperialism in space’, ''Space Policy'', Vol. 11, No. 1, pp41-52; and A. Marshall(1993) 'Ethics and the extraterrestrial environment', ''Journal of Applied Philosophy'', Vol. 10, No 2, pp227-237.</ref> His writings on the latter subject have been cited as insightful but are usually regarded by scientists and engineers as being too radically '[[Environmental movement|environmental]]'<ref>Almar, I. (2002) 'What could COSPAR do to protect the planetary and space environment?', Advances in Space Research', Volume 30, Issue 6, 1577–1588.</ref><ref>Fogg, MJ (2000) 'The ethical dimensions of space settlement', Volume 16, Issue 3, 16 July 2000, Pages 205–211</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg17723765.100-the-word-cosmic-preservationist.html|title=Cosmic Preservationist|publisher=[[New Scientist]]|date=Jan 3, 2003}}</ref> especially his calls for the protection of the Martian landscape.<ref>McArthur, Dan and Idil Boran, "Agent-Centered Restrictions and the Ethics of Space Exploration" in Journal of Social Philosophy vol. 35 No. 1 (Spring 2004) pp. 148–163.</ref>
In early 2016, Marshall began a new project in urban ecology called [http://www.frankencities.com Frankencities]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Strochlic|first=N.|date=2018|title=Voici à quoi pourraient ressembler nos villes en 2121|url=http://www.nationalgeographic.fr/sciences/2018/01/voici-quoi-pourraient-ressembler-nos-villes-en-2121|journal=National Geographic|volume=233|issue=2|pages=28|via=}}</ref><ref>Micu, A. (2018) [https://www.zmescience.com/science/ecotopia-project-cities/ Ecotopia 2121 shows what perfectly ecofriendly cities may look like], ZMEScience, Jan 29th, 2018</ref> which details the worst-case scenarios of emerging environmental problems in a series of cities around the world whilst comparing them to the insights offered by the Dr. [[Frankenstein]] story.<ref>Marshall, A. et al, "[http://journal.urbantranscripts.org/article/frankencities-urban-horrorscapes-near-future-alan-marshall-nanthawan-kaenkaew/ Frankencities: Urban Horrorscapes of Our Near Future]" in Urban Transcripts Journal, Vol. 1 No. 3 (Autumn 2017)</ref> With projects such as these, Marshall has often been labeled as 'anti-science'. In response, he has explained he is a 'science critic' and not 'anti-science' (in the same manner that a 'film critic' is not 'anti-film').
For the Frankencities project and for the Ecotopia 2121 project, Marshall developed a novel urban design [[methodology]] known as [http://www.ecotopia2121.com/single-post/2016/09/13/The-Fantasy-Method-of-Urban-Design 'The Literary Method of Urban Design'], which is not so much about design but more about inventing new social change strategies.
==Fiction== Alan Marshall is an award-winning writer of fiction. His works of fiction include an historical novel, ''Lancewood'', about an iconic New Zealand plant, and a [[science fiction]] radio drama called ''This Pointless Thing Called Life'' that was broadcast on [[NPR]] and XM Satellite Radio in the USA. In 2001 ''This Pointless Thing Called Life'' received the "Silver Award" from the Mark Time Awards by a panel that included Grammy-award winner [[Phil Proctor]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Mark Time/Ogle Award winners|year=2001|url=http://www.greatnorthernaudio.com/MarkTime/MarkTime-winners.html|work=Mark Time Awards|publisher=Jerry Stearns, David Ossman|accessdate=22 Sep 2012}}</ref>
Along with Peter Jackson's ''[[Lord of the Rings]]'' movie trilogy, ''This Pointless Thing Called Life'' was nominated for a [[Sir Julius Vogel Award|Vogel Award]] in the category "Best Long Form dramatic science fiction and fantasy production made in New Zealand in the year 2002".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sffanz.org.nz/sjv/sjvNominations-2002.shtml|title=Sir Julius Vogel Award Nominations - 2002|publisher=SFFANZ|accessdate=22 Sep 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.locusmag.com/SFAwards/Db/SirJuliusVogelNomList.html#3363-2001 |title=Sir Julius Vogel Nominees List |work=The LOCUS Index to SF Awards |publisher=Mark R. Kelly and Locus Publications |accessdate=22 Sep 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006235349/http://www.locusmag.com/SFAwards/Db/SirJuliusVogelNomList.html |archivedate=2012-10-06 |df= }}</ref> Like his scholarly writings, Marshall's fiction explores the relationships between "humans and technology" and between "humans and nature".
The sequel to "This Pointless Thing Called Life" was another award-winning full-length radio feature broadcast in four parts on XM Satellite and by some NPR stations in 2003. This sequel was titled 'This Miserable Thing Called Life".
==Books== * Alan Marshall (2016) ''Ecotopia 2121: A Vision of Our Future Green Utopia -- in 100 Cities'', Arcade Publ: NY. {{ISBN|9781628726008}} * Alan Marshall (2009) ''[https://www.northatlanticbooks.com/shop/wild-design/ Wild Design: Ecofriendly Innovations Inspired by Nature]'', North Atlantic Books: Berkeley. {{ISBN|978-1-55643-790-8}} * Alan Marshall (2006) ''[https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/8474334?q&versionId=9780677 Dangerous Dawn: The New Nuclear Age]'', BNI: Melbourne. * Alan Marshall (2002) ''The Unity of Nature'', Imperial College Press/World Scientific: London & Singapore {{ISBN|1-86094-330-6}} * Alan Marshall (1999) ''[http://indrabooks.com/2007/08/05/lancewood/ Lancewood]'', Indra Publishers: Melbourne. {{ISBN|0-9585805-1-0}}
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{Infobox landform | name = Asarlık Hills
Asarlık Tepeler | other_name = | photo = | photo_width = | photo_alt = | photo_caption = | map = Turkey | map_width = Location of Asarlık Hills in Turkey. | map_caption = | map_alt = | relief = yes | label = Asarlık Hills | label_position = right | mark = | marker_size = | location = Asarlık, [[Nallıhan]], [[Ankara Province]], Turkey | coordinates = {{coord|40|19|02|N|31|24|50|E|type:landmark_region:TR|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | range = | part_of = | elevation_ft = | elevation_ref = | surface_elevation_ft = | surface_elevation_ref = | highest_point = | highest_elevation = | highest_coords = | length = | width = | area = {{Convert|52.374|ha|acres}} | depth = | drop = | formed_by = | geology = | age = | orogeny = | topo = | operator = | designation = | free_label_1 = | free_data_1 = | free_label_2 = | free_data_2 = | website = | embed = }} '''Asarlık Hills''' ({{lang-tr|Asarlık Tepeler}}) are hills located in [[Ankara Province]], central Turkey. The area is a registered [[List of natural monuments of Turkey|natural monument of the country]]. It is {{convert|24|km|mi|abbr=on}} away from the center of [[Nallıhan]] district in Ankara Province, and situated in Asarlık location within the boundaries of [[Danişment, Nallıhan|Danişment]] and [[Uzunöz, Nallıhan|Uzunöz]] villages. The area constitutes rare examples of [[cuesta]] [[geomorphology]] formed by the [[abrasion (geology)|abrasion]] of clay layers with different resistances. It covers an area of {{convert|52.374|ha|abbr=on}}. Being of both scientific and visual interest, the area with hills was registered a natural monument on August 22, 1994. ==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |url=http://bolge9.ormansu.gov.tr/9bolge/AnaSayfa/ilsube/ankarasube/tabiataniti.aspx?sflang=tr |publisher=Orman ve Su İşleri Bakanlığı 9. Bölge Müdürlüğü |title=Ankara Asarlık Tepeler Tabiat Anıt Kaydı |language=Turkish |accessdate=2017-01-17 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.nallihan.bel.tr/index.php?modul=10_3&id=13 |publisher=Nallıhan Belediyesi |title=Kültürel Zenginlikler |language=Turkish |accessdate=2017-01-17 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.milliparklar.gov.tr/belge/ta.pdf |publisher=Milli Parklar |title=Türkiye'nin Tabiat Anıtları |language=Turkish |accessdate=2017-01-17 }} }} {{Natural monuments of Turkey}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Asarlik Hills}} [[Category:Hills of Turkey]] [[Category:Natural monuments of Turkey]] [[Category:Landforms of Ankara Province]] [[Category:Nallıhan]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1994]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Turkey]] {{Ankara-geo-stub}} {{Protected-area-stub}}

page.title: Bahía Portete – Kaurrele National Natural Park

revision.text:
{{Infobox protected area | name = Bahía Portete – Kaurrele National Natural Park | alt_name = PNN Bahía Portete – Kaurrele | iucn_category = | photo = Bahia hondita.JPG | photo_alt = | photo_caption = Bahía Hondita, close to the park | photo_width = | map = Colombia | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_width = | relief = 1 | label =  PNN Bahía Portete – Kaurrele | label_position = right | mark = Blue_pog.svg | marker_size = 10px | location = {{COL}} | nearest_city = [[Uribia]] | coordinates = {{coord|12|07|00|N|72|02|00|W|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = | area_ha = 14080 | designation = [[List of national parks of Colombia|National Natural Park]] | authorized = | created = | established = 20 December 2014 | designated = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | governing_body = | administrator = [[National System of Protected Areas (Colombia)|SINAP]] | operator = | owner = | world_heritage_site = | website = | url = {{URL|http://www.parquesnacionales.gov.co/portal/es/parques-nacionales/parque-nacional-natural-bahia-portete/|Official website}} | child = | embedded = }} '''Bahía Portete – Kaurrele National Natural Park''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]]: '''''PNN Bahía Portete – Kaurrele''''') is a [[List of national parks of Colombia|national natural park]] in [[Uribia, La Guajira|Uribia]], [[La Guajira]], [[Colombia]]. The northernmost national park of mainland South America is located at the [[Caribbean natural region|Caribbean]] coast of the La Guajira peninsula in [[Bahia Portete (La Guajira, Colombia)|Bahía Portete]], between [[Cabo de la Vela]] and [[Punta Gallinas]]. Established on December 20, 2014, it is the most recently designated national park of the country. As of 2017, 59 nationally defined protected areas are incorporated in Colombia. The park hosts a high number of marine and terrestrial species. == Description == {{Location mark | image = Colombia - La Guajira - Uribia.svg | overlay = | width = 290 | caption = Bahía Portete Park is located in the northern part of the municipality Uribia | alt = | float = right | type = thumb | label = | position = | font_size = | background = | mark = Green pog.svg | mark_width = 12 | mark_alt = | mark_link = | x = 680 | y = 115 }} Bahía Portete – Kaurrele National Natural Park, with an area of {{convert|14080|ha|acre}}, is located in the extreme north of Colombia, at the northern coast of La Guajira peninsula between [[Cabo de la Vela]] and [[Punta Gallinas]], Colombia's mainland northernmost point. The park is within the boundaries of the municipality [[Uribia, La Guajira|Uribia]]. The climate is hot and arid, due to the [[desert]] of La Guajira. Average temperatures range between {{convert|28|and|30|C|F}}. The coastal area is characterised by humidity caused by the inland winds.{{es}} [http://www.colparques.net/PORTETE Bahía Portete] – Colparques The marine bay area has an average depth of {{convert|9|m|ft}}, ranging from {{convert|3|to|20|m|ft}}. At the [[Spanish conquest of the Muisca|Spanish conquest]] in the sixteenth century, the bay was known as ''El Portichuelo'', an area where slaves were brought into [[New Kingdom of Granada|Colonial Colombia]]. The sparsely populated area is inhabited by approximately 500 indigenous [[Wayuu people|Wayuu]].Gutiérrez Moreno et al., 2008, p.191{{es}} [http://www.elespectador.com/noticias/medio-ambiente/nueva-reserva-de-bahia-portete-aumenta-areas-protegidas-articulo-534590 Nueva reserva de Bahía Portete aumenta áreas protegidas en el país] – [[El Espectador]] On April 18, 2004, approximately forty paramilitaries tortured and assassinated six people, four of which were women. They burned various houses and dishonoured their cemeteries. More than 600 Wayuu fled to Venezuela.{{es}} [http://www.elespectador.com/noticias/medio-ambiente/bahia-portete-regalo-de-navidad-articulo-534419 Bahía Portete, regalo de Navidad] – [[El Espectador]] Bahía Portete – Kaurrele National Natural Park was designated number 59 of the National Natural Parks of Colombia to protect the marine and littoral ecosystems of the La Guajira peninsula on December 20, 2014.{{es}} [http://www.parquesnacionales.gov.co/portal/es/en-esquina-norte-de-la-guajira-bahia-portete/ En esquina norte de la Guajira, Bahía Portete] – Parques Nacionales Naturales de Colombia The declaration of the park as a protected area was initiated in 2003. The [[indigenous peoples of Colombia|indigenous communities]] of the [[Wayuu people|Wayuu]], Kamushiwoü, Alijunao, Yariwanischi, Puerto Portete, Ian, Youlepa, Kayuuswaarraaloü and Punta Cosos Espacios contributed in the planning of the establishment of the protected area.{{es}} [http://www.parquesnacionales.gov.co/portal/es/parques-nacionales/parque-nacional-natural-bahia-portete/ Parque Nacional Natural Bahía Portete – Kaurrele] – Parques Nacionales Naturales de Colombia{{es}} [http://www.elheraldo.co/la-guajira/bahia-portete-parque-natural-tiene-aval-wayuu-171445 Bahía Portete: parque natural tiene aval wayuu] – [[El Heraldo (Colombia)|El Heraldo]] At the declaration of the park, [[List of presidents of Colombia|president of Colombia]] [[Juan Manuel Santos]] said "Biodiversity is to Colombia, what oil is for the Arabs".{{es}} [http://www.minambiente.gov.co/index.php/normativa/2-noticias/1610-nuevo-parque-nacional-natural-colombia-bahia-portete Nuevo Parque Nacional Natural de Colombia Bahía Portete] – [[Ministry of Environment (Colombia)|Ministerio de Ambiente, Colombia]] Mining and industrial fishing are prohibited.{{es}} [http://www.eltiempo.com/estilo-de-vida/ciencia/bahia-portete-guajira-es-parque-nacional-natural/15007423 La bahía sagrada que se volvió parque nacional] – [[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]] === Biodiversity === [[File:Caracara cheriway.JPG|thumb|right|290px|Crested caracara in La Guajira desert]] {{main|Biodiversity of Colombia}} Bahía Portete – Kaurrele Park comprises 25 species of reptiles and amphibians, relatively few mammals and marine fauna of 217 species have been registered in Bahía Portete.{{es}} [http://soybiodiversidadaguilarleon.blogspot.com.co/2016/10/parque-nacional-natural-bahia-portete.html Biodiversidad Parque Nacional Natural Bahía Portete – Kaurrele] The [[biodiversity of Colombia|biodiversity]] of the park is rich in various other species.Gutiérrez Moreno et al., 2008, p.199Díaz Pulido, 1997, p.138 ==== Fauna ==== {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" ! Name ! Species ! [[File:Stephanosoenia michelinii 1.jpg|center|200px]] |- |} ==== Flora ==== The coastal Bahía Portete Park is richer in flora than the surrounding desert. Common land plants are the cactus ''[[Opuntia wentiana]]'' and the mangrove tree ''[[Avicennia germinans]]''.Díaz Pulido, 1997, p.89 Meadows of sea grasses of ''[[Thalassia testudinum]]'' and ''[[Syringodium]]'' are widely distributed in the marine portion of the park.Díaz Pulido, 1997, p.48Díaz Pulido, 1997, p.52 == Other protected areas in La Guajira == [[File:SFF Los Flamencos.JPG|thumb|right|290px|Los Flamencos Sanctuary, west of Bahía Portete in La Guajira]] La Guajira contains eight protected areas, three national and five regional. * [[Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta]] * [[Los Flamencos Sanctuary]] * [[Serranía de Macuira]] * Manantial de Cañaverales * Distrito de Manejo Integrado Musichi * Distrito de Manejo Integrado del Perijá * Reserva Natural de los Montes de Oca * Distrito de Manejo Integrado Bañaderos y Alto Camarones {{clearboth}} == Gallery == File:Cabo de la Vela, Colombia.jpg|Cabo de la Vela
west of Bahía Portete File:Opuntia wentiana (8609027102).jpg|''Opuntia wentiana'' File:Vejetación Guajira - panoramio.jpg|Typical cactus vegetation File:La Mujer Wayuu, La Guajira Colombiana.jpg|Indigenous [[Wayuu people|Wayuu]] File:Dunas de Taroa.JPG|Taroa dunes
east of Bahía Portete {{clearboth}} == See also == {{Portal|Colombia|Environment}} * [[List of national parks of Colombia]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} === Bibliography === * {{cite LSA |last=Gutiérrez Moreno |first=Carolina |last2=Alonso C. |first2=David |last3=Segura Quintero |first3=Carolina |year=2008 |title=Diseño de un área marina protegida para Bahía Portete – La Guajira, Caribe Colombiano |url=http://www.scielo.org.co/pdf/mar/v37n2/v37n2a10.pdf |journal=Boletín Investigaciones Marinas y Costeras, INVEMAR |volume=37 |pages=189–212 |accessdate=2017-01-30}} * {{cite LSA |last=Díaz Pulido |first=Guillermo |year=1997 |title=Informe nacional sobre el estado de la biodiversidad en Colombia – Ecosistemas marinos y costeros |url=http://www.invemar.org.co/redcostera1/invemar/docs/2200IEAMC1997.pdf |publisher=INVEMAR |pages=1–151 |accessdate=2017-01-30}} {{Biodiversity of Colombia|state=collapsed}} {{Protected areas of Colombia|state=expanded}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bahia Portete - Kaurrele National Natural Park}} [[Category:National parks of Colombia]] [[Category:Nature reserves in Colombia]] [[Category:Geography of La Guajira Department]] [[Category:Protected areas of the Caribbean]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 2014]] [[Category:2014 establishments in Colombia]]

revision.comment: /* Work */ Legenda Christiani is Latin not vernacular
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=May 2014}} [[Image:Bohuslav Balbín.jpg|thumb|Bohuslav Balbín]] '''Bohuslav Balbín''' (3 December 1621 Hradec Králové – 29 November 1688 Prague) was a [[Czech people|Czech]] writer, historian, geographer and [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]], called the "Czech [[Pliny the Younger|Pliny]]". He became well known also as an advocate of the Czech language in the time of incoming germanization of the Czech lands.
==Life== {{unreferenced section|date=February 2017}} Balbín was born in [[Hradec Králové]] into a middle class Roman Catholic family. He was educated mostly in the Jesuit schools, he soon joined the Society of Jesus. After finishing studies in philosophy at [[University of Olomouc]], he taught in Jesuit colleges in Prague, [[Třeboň]], [[Brno]], [[Jičín]], [[Jindřichův Hradec]] and [[Český Krumlov]].
After writing of several textbooks and didactic theatre plays, he also became acquainted with historical sources of archives and libraries. His entire life was devoted to collecting and editing materials about Czech history, and his researches have often been utilized by the [[Bollandists]]. Balbín died, aged 66, in [[Prague]].
== Work ==
He wrote over thirty works, the most important from which is ''Miscellanea Historica regni Bohemiae'' ("Varieties from the History of the Czech Kingdom" ", 6 vols., Prague, 1679–87), in which he described the [[geography]], [[natural history]], and chief [[History|historical]] events of his native land. The work includes brief ''[[Biography|vita]]e'' of prominent Czechs. The sections of the work: *Miscellanea historica regni Bohemiae - History of the kingdom of Bohemia *Liber naturalis - The Nature of Bohemia *Liber popularis - The population *Liber chorographicus - Topography *Liber hagiographicus – Czech Saints *Liber parochialis – The Parishes *Liber episcopalis - The Archdiocese of Prague *Liber regalis - Rulers *Liber epistolaris - Series of letters *Bohemia Docta - Czech literature and teaching *Liber de seu curialis magistratibus et officiis curialibus regem Bohemiae - Paper on Courts and Offices of the Czech Crown
Bohuslav Balbín (Balbinus) is known in Czech Lands mostly for his "Apology for the Slavic and especially Czech language", written in Latin. He was the first to edit the ancient [[Legenda Christiani|chronicle]] of the tenth century<ref>Introduction to the edition of 1902, Dr. Pekár</ref> known as the ''Life of St. Ludmilla and Martyrdom of St. Wenceslas'', which is considered the oldest historical work written in the Czech lands by a Czech (written in Latin). Balbinus wrote also ''De archiepiscopis Bohemiae'' ("The Archbishops of Bohemia", Prague, 1682) and ''Bohemia Sancta, sive de sanctis Bohemiae, Moraviae, Silesiae, Lusatiae'' ("Sacred Bohemia, or the Saints of Bohemia, Moravia, Silesia and Lusatia" Prague, 1682). His book ''Vita beatae Joannis Nepomuceni martyris'' (Life of Saint and martyr John of Nepomuk) was published in Prague, 1670, is in large part responsible for the developed legend of Saint [[John of Nepomuk]].<ref>It was reprinted in the [[Bollandists]]' ''Acta sanctorum'' III, May, pp 668-80.</ref> Balbin also wrote one reference book about [[Stylistics (field of study)|stylistics]] (1666) and two works devoted to [[rhetoric]] (1677, 1688) <ref>[http://www.ujc.cas.cz/lingviste/balbin-bohuslav.html Bohuslav Balbín (Department of the Czech language - in Czech)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104192323/http://www.ujc.cas.cz/lingviste/balbin-bohuslav.html |date=January 4, 2015 }}</ref>
== Bibliography == * Legatio Apollinis coelestis ad universitatem Pragensem etc. * Vita venerabilis Arnesti (biography of [[Arnošt of Pardubice]], the first Archbishop of Prague), 1664 * Verisimilia humaniorum disciplinarunm seu judicium privatum de omni letterarum, quasi humaniores appellent, artificio. 1666. * Dissertatio apologetica pro lingua Slavonica, praecipue Bohemica. 1775. (In Czech: Obrana jazyka slovanského, zvláště českého. 1869) * Vita S. Joannis Nepomuceni sigilli sacramentalis protomartyris * Epitome rerum Bohemicarum seu historia Boleslaviensis, 1677 (The book about history of [[Stará Boleslav]]) * Quaesita oratoria seu eloquentiae praecepta. 1677 * De archiepiscopis Bohemiae * Brevis tractatio de amplificatione oratoria. 1688 * Miscellanea historica regni Bohemiae, 1679–88<ref>[https://www.phil.muni.cz/fil/scf/komplet/balbin.html Bohuslav Balbín - in Czech)]</ref> * Vita et passio sancti Wenceslai et sanctae Ludmilae aviae eius
==See also== * [[List of Czech writers]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02216b.htm ''Catholic Encyclopedia'': "Boleslaus Balbinus"] *[http://baila.net/autor/172674192/bohuslav-balbin Bohuslav Balbín at Czechoslovak book network Baila.net]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Balbin, Bohuslav}} [[Category:Czech male writers]] [[Category:Czech philosophers]] [[Category:Czech Jesuits]] [[Category:Czech Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Czech historians]] [[Category:Linguists from the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Czech geographers]] [[Category:People from Hradec Králové]] [[Category:1621 births]] [[Category:1688 deaths]] [[Category:Palacký University alumni]]

revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "A low-lying flatland region encompassing the northern part of the Caspian Sea" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|A low-lying flatland region encompassing the northern part of the Caspian Sea}} {{More footnotes|date=February 2008}} [[Image:Caspian Depression - NASA (edited).jpg|thumb|250px|right|Caspian Depression and north Caspian Sea from space]]
The '''Caspian Depression''' ({{lang-rus|Прикаспи́йская ни́зменность|p=prʲɪkɐˈspʲijskəjə ˈnʲizmʲɪnnəsʲtʲ}}, '''Caspian Lowland''') or '''Pricaspian/Peri-Caspian Depression/Lowland''' is a [[lowland|low-lying]] [[Flatland (disambiguation)|flatland]] region encompassing the northern part of the [[Caspian Sea]], the largest enclosed [[body of water]] on [[Earth]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.caspianenvironment.org/newsite/Caspian-Background.htm |title=Caspian Sea » Background |publisher=Caspian Environment Programme |accessdate=2011-02-24 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It is the larger northern part of the wider [[Aral-Caspian Depression]] around the [[Aral Sea|Aral]] and Caspian seas.
The level of the Caspian sea is {{convert|28|m}} below sea level, however several places in the depression are even lower, and among them [[Karagiye]] near [[Aktau]] is the lowest at {{convert|-132|m}}.
The [[Depression (geology)|depression]] lies at the southern end of the [[Ryn Desert]], and is in both [[Kazakhstan]] and [[Russia]]. Most of the Russian Republic of [[Kalmykia]] lies in the Caspian Depression. The [[Volga River]] and the [[Ural River]] flow into the Caspian Sea through this region. The deltas of the Ural and Volga Rivers are extensive wetlands. The North Caspian depression is part of the [[Continental climate|continental]] or [[semi-arid]] desert [[biome]]. The area receives {{convert|300|mm|abbr=on}} of rain per year, on average, and less than 10% of the region is irrigated.
The Caspian Depression is below sea-level, consisting of large areas of [[marshland]]s in the eastern region. It is one of the largest flat lowland areas in [[Central Asia]], covering approximately {{convert|200000|km²|abbr=on}}. The area is very rich in underground oil and gas reserves, and oil and natural gas pipelines cross the depression from north to south and east to west. Many geologists believe the Caspian Sea and the depression were formed by [[tectonic]] forces. Some of them also believe that the North Caspian depression became separated from the open ocean in ancient times to form an enormous salt lake. Part of the ancient [[Silk Road]] ran through this region. The two largest cities in the depression are [[Astrakhan]] in Russia, and [[Atyrau]] in Kazakhstan. Today, the region is used mainly for livestock raising.
The depression is also noted for [[salt dome]]s, particularly Volgograd salt. It increases dramatically as one travels from the [[Ryn Desert]] toward the Caspian Sea. Russian satellite photos have revealed huge deposits of salt domes (about 1,200), in the Caspian Depression in western Kazakhstan. One dome, called the [[Chelkar Deposit]], covers an area of {{convert|3237|km²|abbr=on}} and is nearly {{convert|8|km|0}} deep.
The southern region of the depression, or the north coast of the Caspian Sea, is characterized by large development of damp sites resulting from [[tidal]] phenomena. The depression is also home to a large number of [[insect]] [[species]], with several thousand different species likely living in the region around the Caspian Sea. Studies have shown that [[water pollution]], mostly coming from the Volga River, poses a serious threat to the [[biodiversity]] of the Caspian Depression. Water pollution is contributed mainly by [[Industry|industrial]], [[agricultural]], and household discharges.
==References== {{reflist}} * Evaporites of North Border of North Caspian Depression – ''Internet Geology News Letter No. 178'', January 13, 2003. * [http://www.spacetoday.org/Satellites/SatBytes/SaltDomes.html Space Today Online].

{{Infobox lake |name = Chott Melrhir | image = Chott Melrhir NASA.jpg |caption = View from space. Note that most of the lake is already dried up in this picture. |image_bathymetry = |caption_bathymetry = |location = | coords = {{Coord|34|20|N|6|20|E|type:waterbody_region:DZ|display=title}} |type = [[Endorheic]] [[salt lake]] |inflow = |outflow = |catchment = {{convert|68750|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}<ref name=j1>{{cite journal|url=http://www.larhyss.net/pdf/journal/7/8_Benkhaled_et_al_Larhyss_Journal_7_Juin_2008.pdf|title=Detecting trends in annual discharge and precipitation in the Chott Melghir basin in Southeastern Algeria|author1=Benkhaled A.|author2=Bouziane M.T|author3=Achour B.|journal=Larhyss Journal|issn=1112-3680|volume=7|date=June 2008|pages=103–119|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100614023034/http://www.larhyss.net/pdf/journal/7/8_Benkhaled_et_al_Larhyss_Journal_7_Juin_2008.pdf|archivedate=2010-06-14}}</ref><ref name=gov/> |basin_countries = Algeria |length = |width = |area ={{convert|6700|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}<ref name=bse/> |depth = |max-depth = |volume = |elevation = |cities = |embedded = {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = Ramsar | designation1_offname = Chott Melghir | designation1_date = 4 June 2003 | designation1_number = 1296<ref>{{Cite web|title=Chott Melghir|website=[[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Sites Information Service|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/1296|accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref>}} }} {{Location map |Algeria |mark=<!--dot-->Blue pog.svg |lat_deg=34|lat_min=30 |lon_deg=6|lon_min=3 |caption= |position=right |width=240 |float=right }} '''[[Chott]] Melrhir''' ({{Lang-ar|شط ملغيغ}}) also known as '''Chott Melghir''' or '''Chott Melhir''' is an [[endorheic]] salt lake in northeastern [[Algeria]]. It the westernmost part of a series of [[Depression (geology)|depressions]], which extend from the [[Gulf of Gabès]] into the [[Sahara]]. They were created between [[Miocene]] and [[Early Pleistocene]] as a result of compression accompanying the formation of the [[Atlas Mountains]].<ref>Andrew Goudie (2002) [https://books.google.com/books?id=v911L1sq1FkC&pg=PA113 ''Great Warm Deserts of the World: Landscapes and Evolution''], Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|0-19-924515-0}}, p. 113</ref> With the maximum area of about {{convert|6700|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}, Chott Melrhir is the largest lake in Algeria.<ref name=bse>В. М. Котляков [http://slovari.yandex.ru/~%D0%BA%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B8/%D0%93%D0%B5%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%84%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B5%20%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F/%D0%9C%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B3%D0%B8%D1%80/ Мельгир (Chott Melrhir)], Словарь современных географических названий (Dictionary of modern geographical names), 2003–2006</ref> It lies almost entirely below the sea level and contains the lowest point in Algeria, {{convert|-40|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}}.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=pqanFyF6nI0C&pg=PA10 ''CIA World Factbook 2010''] {{ISBN|1-60239-727-9}}, p. 10</ref> Its size varies over the year and is usually larger than {{convert|130|km|mi|abbr=on}} from east to west.<ref name=brit>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/374156/Chott-Melrhir Chott Melrhir], Encyclopædia Britannica on-line</ref> The nearby cities are [[Biskra]] (60 km north-east), [[El Oued]] and [[Touggourt]] (85 km south).<ref name=b1>Robert Mepham, R. H. Hughes, J. S. Hughes (1992) [https://books.google.com/books?id=VLjafeXa3gMC&pg=PA23 ''A Directory of African Wetlands''], IUCN, {{ISBN|2-88032-949-3}} pp. 23–24</ref>
==Hydrology, geology and geography== During the rain season in winter, the lake is filled by numerous [[wadi]] (periodically drying rivers), mostly from north and north-west. The largest of them are the [[Djedi River|Djedi]] and Arab<ref name=gov/><ref>[http://www.abhs.dz/new_site/chottmelghir.asp Chott Melhrir] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110405073204/http://www.abhs.dz/new_site/chottmelghir.asp |date=2011-04-05}}</ref> running from west to east down the slopes of [[Aurès Mountains]].<ref>{{cite book|language=French|author=Jean-Louis Ballais|url=http://physio-geo.revues.org/1173|title=Des oueds mythiques aux rivières artificielles: l'hydrographie du Bas-Sahara algérien|pages=107–127}}</ref> Others include [[Abiod Valley|Abiod]], Beggour Mitta, [[Biskra Province|Biskra]], Bir Az Atrous, Cheria, Demmed, Dermoun, Derradj, Djedeida, Djemorah, Halail, Horchane, Ittel, Mechra, Melh, Mzi, Messad, Oum El Ksob, Soukies, Tadmit and Zeribet.<ref name=j1/><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=bxErAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA159 Annales des mines: Mémoires], Cadrilian-Gœury et Vor. Dalmont, 1880 pp. 154, 159, 172</ref> In summer, the lake and most the rivers feeding it dry out, and Chott Melrhir turns into a [[Dry lake|salt pan]].<ref name=bse/><ref>[http://www.cosmovisions.com/Algerie.htm Algérie. États et Territoires] (in French)</ref> The annual water evaporation varies between 9.6 and 20 km<sup>3</sup>, and evaporation from soil nearby the lake can reach 14 km<sup>3</sup>.<ref name=gov/>
Chott Melrhir is separated from the nearby Chott Meorouane, which lies south-west, by a stripe of permanently dry land which can be as narrow as 4 kilometers in some places.<ref name=b1/> The bottom of the lake is mostly composed of [[gypsum]] and mud and is covered in salt in summer. The lake emits a garlic-like odor.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=uzgVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA377 ''The Annals and Magazine of Natural History: Including Zoology, Botany, and Geology''], Taylor and Francis (1871) p. 377</ref> Although the dry soil in and around the lake appears arable, it is nearly barren due to the high concentration of salt. For the same reason, the soil absorbs much condensation overnight that keeps it partly humid during much of the day.<ref>Henry Woodward [https://books.google.com/books?id=wYcPAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA28 ''Geological Magazine'', Volume 1], Cambridge University Press., 1864, p. 28</ref>
==Climate== [[File:Houbara035.JPG|thumb|left|upright|[[Houbara bustard]]]] The climate in the Chott Melrhir is hot and arid with high evaporation and low precipitation. The average lowest and highest temperatures are 11.4 and 34.2 °C, respectively, and the minimum temperature is about 0 °C. Annual precipitation is below 160 mm. The winds have a speed between 2.7 and 5.3 m/s and are mostly directed south-east between June and September and north-west between autumn and early spring. [[Dust storm|Sandstorms]] are more frequent in winter and late summer and last 39 days per year on average.<ref name=j1/><ref name=gov/>
==Flora and fauna== The shallow waters of the lake contain scarce vegetation composed of 72 species of plants which have adapted to salty water, such as Parish's glasswort (''[[Arthrocnemum subterminale]]''), sea lavender (''[[Limonium]]''), rushes (''[[Juncus]]''), glasswort (''[[Salicornia]]''), ''[[Sarcocornia]]'', bulrush (''[[Scirpus]]'') and seepweeds (''[[Suaeda]]''). Some species are unique for Algeria and 14 are endemic, such as ''Fagonia microphylla'', ''Oudneya africana'', ''Zygophyllum cornutum'', ''Limoniastrum feii'' and ''Ammosperma cinerea''.<ref name=gov>[http://www.dgf.org.dz/zones_humides/fdr/melghir.pdf Chott Melghir] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091123091922/http://www.dgf.org.dz/zones_humides/fdr/melghir.pdf |date=November 23, 2009 }}, Ministere de l'Agriculture. Direction Generale des Forets (in French)</ref> They grown up to 30 cm in height and host relatively rich avifauna, mostly [[Anas|ducks]], [[sandgrouse]], [[houbara bustard]] (''Chlamydotis undulata'') and [[greater flamingo]] (''Phoenicopterus roseus'').<ref name=b1/><ref>Erik Carp (1980) [https://books.google.com/books?id=RNmtBYWb0w0C&pg=PA28 ''Directory of Wetlands of International Importance in the Western Palearctic''], IUCN, {{ISBN|2-88032-300-2}}, p. 28</ref> Lake waters are saturated with salt with concentrations reaching 0.4 kg/L<ref name=gov/> and sustain only few animal species, such as [[brine shrimp]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=J. Limnol.|volume=65|issue=2|pages=83–88|year=2006|title=Large branchiopods (Branchiopoda: Anostraca, Notostraca and Spinicaudata) from the salt lakes of Algeria|author=Samraoui, Boudjéma|url=http://www.iii.to.cnr.it/pubblicaz/jl65_2/02_samraoui.pdf|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Wild boars, [[golden jackal]]s, hares and foxes were observed around the lake.<ref name=gov/> In June 2003, Chott Melrhir was included to the [[List of Ramsar wetlands of international importance]].<ref>[http://www.ramsar.org/pdf/sitelist.pdf The List of Wetlands of International Importance], p. 5</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Portal|Wetlands}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091123091922/http://www.dgf.org.dz/zones_humides/fdr/melghir.pdf A detailed report on the lake by the Ministry of Agriculture of Algeria with the map of the area] (in French)
{{Wetlands}}

revision.text:
[[Image:DoubleDig.gif|right|Double digging with spade and fork loosens the soil, to increase drainage and aeration.]]
'''Double digging''' is a [[gardening]] technique used to increase [[soil]] drainage and aeration. It involves the loosening of two layers of [[soil]], and the addition of organic matter.
Double digging is typically done when cultivating soil in a new garden, or when deep top-soil is required. On poor or heavy soils, or for vegetable gardens, double digging might be required every 3–5 years. In other cases, double digging is only really needed on starting a new garden, or on total replanting.
First the top layer is dug off with a spade, forming a shallow trench, and then the under-layer (at the bottom of the trench) is dug with a fork. When breaking up the lower layer, organic matter such as [[compost]] is usually added to the soil. If the soil is in need of other minerals like [[gypsum]] or [[phosphorus]] this can also be added here.
A second trench is then started, backfilling the first trench. This process is repeated until the whole bed has been treated. There will be soil left over from the first trench, which is used to fill the last trench.
Walking on top of the bed will crush/flatten it, so the gardener must be sure to protect the soil from too much foot traffic
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.rhs.org.uk/Advice/Profile?PID=133 Royal Horticulture Society: Double digging] * https://web.archive.org/web/20080415183343/http://www.farm-garden.com/feature/double_digging_gardeners_workout * [http://www.organicgardening.com/learn-and-grow/double-digging-how OrganicGardening.com: Double-Digging How-To]
[[Category:Horticulture and gardening]]
{{Horticulture-stub}}

[[File:Yarlung Tsangpo river tibet.jpg|thumb|Dendritic drainage: the [[Yarlung Tsangpo River]], Tibet, seen from space: snow cover has melted in the valley system.]] In [[geomorphology]], '''drainage systems''', also known as '''river systems''', are the patterns formed by the [[stream]]s, [[river]]s, and [[lake]]s in a particular [[drainage basin]]. They are governed by the topography of the land, whether a particular region is dominated by hard or soft rocks, and the gradient of the land. [[Geomorphologist]]<nowiki/>s and [[hydrologist]]<nowiki/>s often view streams as being part of drainage basins. A drainage basin is the [[Topography|topographic]] region from which a stream receives [[Surface runoff|runoff]], [[throughflow]], and [[groundwater flow]]. The number, size, and shape of the drainage basins found in an area vary and the larger the [[topographic map]], the more information on the drainage basin is available.<ref name="physicalgeography.net">[http://www.physicalgeography.net/fundamentals/10aa.html Pidwirny, M., (2006). "The Drainage Basin Concept". ''Fundamentals of Physical Geography,'' 2nd Edition.]</ref>
==Drainage patterns== According to the configuration of the [[Channel (geography)|channels]], drainage systems can fall into one of several categories known as drainage patterns. Drainage patterns depend on the [[topography]] and [[geology]] of the land.<ref name="uwsp.edu"/>
=== Accordant drainage patterns === A drainage system is described as accordant if its pattern correlates to the structure and relief of the landscape over which it flows.<ref name="uwsp.edu"/>
[[File:Dendritic Drainage pattern.jpg|thumb|left|Dendritic drainage patterns]]
====Dendritic drainage pattern==== Dendritic drainage systems (from [[Greek language|Greek]] {{lang|grc|δενδρίτης}}, ''dendrites'', "of or parallel to a tree") are not straight and are the most common form of drainage system. In a dendritic system, there are many contributing streams (analogous to the twigs of a tree), which are then joined together into the [[tributaries]] of the main river (the branches and the trunk of the tree, respectively). They develop where the river channel follows the slope of the terrain. Dendritic systems form in [[V-shaped valley]]s; as a result, the rock types must be [[impervious]] and [[non-porous]].<ref name=fieldguide>{{cite book| last = Lambert| first = David| title = The Field Guide to Geology| publisher = Checkmark Books| year = 1998| pages =130–131| isbn = 0-8160-3823-6 }}</ref>
[[File:Parallel drainage pattern.jpg|thumb|right|Parallel drainage pattern]]
====Parallel drainage pattern==== A parallel drainage system is a pattern of rivers caused by steep slopes with some [[Terrain|relief]]. Because of the steep slopes, the streams are swift and straight, with very few tributaries, and all flow in the same direction. This system forms on uniformly sloping surfaces, for example, rivers flowing southeast from the [[Aberdare Mountains]] in Kenya.
Parallel drainage patterns form where there is a pronounced slope to the surface. A parallel pattern also develops in regions of parallel, elongate landforms like outcropping resistant rock bands. Tributary streams tend to stretch out in a parallel-like fashion following the slope of the surface. A parallel pattern sometimes indicates the presence of a major fault that cuts across an area of steeply folded bedrock. All forms of transitions can occur between parallel, dendritic, and trellis patterns.
====Trellis drainage pattern==== The geometry of a trellis drainage system is similar to that of a common garden [[trellis (architecture)|trellis]] used to grow vines. As the river flows, along a strike valley, smaller tributaries feed into it from the steep slopes on the sides of mountains. These tributaries enter the main river at approximately 90 degree angle, causing a trellis-like appearance of the drainage system. Trellis drainage is characteristic of folded mountains, such as the [[Appalachian Mountains]] in North America and in the north part of [[Trinidad]].<ref name="uwsp.edu">[http://www.earthonlinemedia.com/ebooks/tpe_3e/title_page.html Ritter, Michael E., ''The Physical Environment: an Introduction to Physical Geography.'' 2006]</ref>
[[File:Rectangular.png|thumb|right|Rectangular drainage pattern]]
====Rectangular drainage pattern==== Rectangular drainage develops on rocks that are of approximately uniform resistance to [[erosion]], but which have two directions of [[Joint (geology)|joining]] at approximately right angles or 90 degrees. The joints are usually less resistant to erosion than the bulk rock so erosion tends to preferentially open the joints and streams eventually develop along the joints. The result is a stream system in which streams consist mainly of straight line segments with right angle bends and tributaries join larger streams at right angles.<ref name="uwsp.edu"/> This pattern can be found with the [[Arun River, China–Nepal|Arun River]] in Nepal.
[[File:Radial.png|thumb|left|Radial drainage pattern]]
====Radial drainage pattern==== In a radial drainage system, the streams radiate outwards from a central high point. [[Volcanos]] usually display excellent radial drainage. They can sometimes also be found on tops of mountains. Other geological features on which radial drainage commonly develops are [[Dome (geology)|domes]] and [[laccolith]]s. On these features the drainage may exhibit a combination of radial patterns. The radical pattern develops when streams flow in different directions from a central peak or dome like structure. In India the [[Amarkantak]] range shows the best example of radial drainage pattern.
====Centripetal drainage pattern==== The centripetal drainage system is similar to the radial drainage system, with the only exception that [https://s3.amazonaws.com/classconnection/602/flashcards/7102602/gif/centripetal_drainage_pattern_-150F745643C3823DD4A.gif radial drainage flows out versus centripetal drainage flows in].
====Deranged drainage pattern==== <!-- This section is linked from [[Lake]] --> A deranged drainage system is a drainage system in [[drainage basin]]s where there is no coherent pattern to the rivers and lakes. It happens in areas where there has been much geological disruption. The classic example is the [[Canadian Shield]]. During the last [[ice age]], the [[topsoil]] was scraped off, leaving mostly bare rock. The melting of the glaciers left land with many irregularities of elevation and a great deal of water to collect in the low points, explaining the large number of lakes which are found in [[Canada]]. The drainage basins are young and are still sorting themselves out. Eventually the system will stabilize.<ref name="physicalgeography.net"/>
[[File:Annular.png|thumb|right|Annular drainage pattern]]
====Annular drainage pattern====
In an annular drainage pattern streams follow a roughly circular or concentric path along a belt of weak rock, resembling in plan a ringlike pattern. It is best displayed by streams draining a maturely dissected [[structural dome]] or [[structural basin|basin]] where erosion has exposed rimming [[Sedimentary rock|sedimentary]] strata of greatly varying degrees of hardness, as in the [[Red Valley (South Dakota)|Red Valley]], which nearly encircles the domal structure of the [[Black Hills]] of [[South Dakota]].
==== Angular drainage pattern ====
Angular drainage patterns form where [[bedrock]] joints and faults intersect at more acute angles than rectangular drainage patterns. Angles are both more and less than 90 degrees.<ref>Easterbrook, Don J (1969). Chapter 7, Origins of Stream Valleys and Drainage Patterns. ''Principles of Geomorphology''. McGraw-Hill Book Company. pp. 148-153. {{ISBN|0-07-018780-0}} (this author defines dendritic, trellis, rectangular, angular, radial, annular, centripetal and parallel drainage patterns)</ref>
=== Discordant drainage patterns=== A drainage pattern is described as discordant if it does not correlate to the topography and geology of the area. Discordant drainage patterns are classified into two main types: ''[[Antecedent drainage stream|antecedent]]'' and ''superimposed'',<ref name="uwsp.edu"/> while ''anteposition'' drainage patterns combine the two. In ''antecedent'' drainage, a river's vertical incision ability matches that of land uplift due to tectonic forces. ''Superimposed'' drainage develops differently: initially, a drainage system develops on a surface composed of 'younger' rocks, but due to denudative activities this surface of younger rocks is removed and the river continues to flow over a seemingly new surface, but one in fact made up of rocks of old geological formation.
== See also ==
* [[Distributary]] * [[Integrated catchment management]] * [[List of unusual drainage systems|'''List of unusual drainage systems''']] * [[River bifurcation]] * [[Stream capture]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://web.mit.edu/star/hydro/ StarHydro – software tool that covers concepts of fluvial geomorphology and watershed hydrology]
{{river morphology}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | name = M. Duane Nellis | order = 21st | image = Duane Nellis.png | image_size = 190 | caption = Nellis in 2017 | predecessor = David Descutner ''(interim)''
Roderick J. McDavis | successor = | term_start = June 12, 2017https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=22w2tvgfcjc | term_end = | title = President of
[[Ohio University]] | footnotes = | signature = | order2 = 16th | title2 = President of
[[Texas Tech University]] | term_start2 = June 13, 2013 | term_end2 = January 22, 2016 | predecessor2 = [[Guy Bailey]] | successor2 = John Opperman ''(interim)'' | order3 = 17th | title3 = [[List of University of Idaho people#Presidents of the University of Idaho|President]] of the
[[University of Idaho]] | term_start3 = July 2009 | term_end3 = May 2013 | predecessor3 = [[Timothy P. White|Timothy White]] | successor3 = [[Chuck Staben]] | birth_date = {{b-da|July 26, 1954}} | birth_place = [[Spokane, Washington]] | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = Ruthie Nellis | children = 2 sons | residence = [[Athens, Ohio]] | alma_mater = [[Montana State University]],
B.S. 1976
[[Oregon State University]],
M.S. 1977, Ph.D. 1980 | profession = Higher Education Administrator and Geographer | website = {{URL|https://www.ohio.edu/president/}} | religion = }} '''Marvin Duane Nellis''' is an American educator and university administrator, currently the president of [[Ohio University]] in [[Athens, Ohio|Athens]]. He was previously the president of [[Texas Tech University]] and the [[University of Idaho]].{{cite news |title=M. Duane Nellis: Not many people know what the M. stands for |first=George |last=Prentice |url=http://www.boiseweekly.com/boise/m-duane-nellis/Content?oid=2371176 |newspaper=[[Boise Weekly]] |date=July 20, 2011 |accessdate=July 5, 2016}}{{cite journal |url=https://issuu.com/uidaho/docs/2009_summer/19 |journal=Here We Have Idaho |agency=(University of Idaho) |title=The Nellis Era has begun |last=Olson |first=Jeff |date=Spring 2009 |page=19}} Earlier academic posts were provost and senior vice president at [[Kansas State University]], and dean of the Eberly College of Arts and Science at [[West Virginia University]]. ==Early life and education== Born in [[Spokane, Washington]], Nellis was raised in [[Western Montana|northwestern]] [[Montana]] and graduated from [[Libby High School]] {{nowrap|in 1972.{{cite news|url=http://www.thewesternnews.com/education/article_cc7f174e-a146-11e2-9a39-0019bb2963f4.html?mode=story|newspaper=The Western News |location=[[Libby, Montana|Libby, MT]]|title=LHS grad to lead Texas Tech |first=Alan Lewis |last=Gerstenecker |date=April 9, 2013 |accessdate=December 18, 2013}}}} He attended [[Montana State University]] in [[Bozeman, Montana|Bozeman]] and earned a bachelor's degree in earth sciences/[[geography]] in 1976. Nellis went to graduate school at [[Oregon State University]] in [[Corvallis, Oregon|Corvallis]], earning a master's in geography in 1977 and a Ph.D. in geography {{nowrap|in 1980.https://www.ttu.edu/administration/president/biography.php{{cite web|url=http://scienceblog.com/community/older/archives/K/5/pub5851.html|publisher=Science Blog|title=M. Duane Nellis returns to Kansas State as Provost |date=February 20, 2004 |agency=Kansas State University |last=May |first=Cheryl |accessdate=December 18, 2013}}}} His doctoral dissertation was on [[remote sensing]] in [[water resource management]].{{cite thesis |type=Ph.D. |title=Water management in the North Deschutes unit irrigation district: geographic perspectives and remote sensing applications |url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/9186062 |first=Martin Duane |last=Nellis |year=1980 |publisher=[[Oregon State University]] |oclc=9186062}} ==Academic career== After graduate school, Nellis has worked for over 30 years in various progressive administrative roles at [[Kansas State University]], [[West Virginia University]], [[University of Idaho]],{{cite web |url=http://www.uidaho.edu/sci/geography/faculty/duanenellis |title=Duane Nellis - Department of Geography, University of Idaho |publisher=[[University of Idaho]] |accessdate=2 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302100050/http://www.uidaho.edu/sci/geography/faculty/duanenellis |archivedate=2 March 2013 |df= }}, [[Texas Tech University]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ttu.edu/administration/president/biography.php |title=Texas Tech University :: Office of the President |publisher=[[Texas Tech University]] |accessdate=3 January 2014}}, and most recently at Ohio University. At Kansas State, Nellis was a department head, associate dean, and after returning from West Virginia (where he served as dean of the Eberly College of Arts and Sciences), served as [[provost (education)|provost]] and senior vice president from 2004 until his departure for the university presidency at Idaho in 2009. He later became president of Texas Tech in June 2013, then most recently became president of Ohio University in 2017. Nellis' research has focused on [[geographic information systems]] and remote sensing, and he is internationally recognized for his work in this area, including receiving numerous university, national and international teaching, research and advising awards, and serving as president {{nowrap|(2002–2003)}} of the [[American Association of Geographers|Association of American Geographers]], president of the [[National Council for Geographic Education]] {{nowrap|(1993–1994),}} and president of [[Gamma Theta Upsilon]], the international honor geographical society {{nowrap|(1999–2000).}} ===University of Idaho=== Nellis arrived at the University of Idaho in [[Moscow, Idaho|Moscow]] in 2009 and led a major $225 million capital campaign,{{cite web |url=http://www.uidaho.edu/inspire |title=Inspiring Futures: Invest in the University of Idaho |publisher=[[University of Idaho]] |accessdate=17 July 2014}} and oversaw over $80 million in campus facility improvements. He created the President’s Diversity Council, enhanced what became a nationally award-winning engagement effort through creation of the Office for Community Partnerships, improved major inter-disciplinary initiatives, and significantly improved business partnerships between the university and business and commodity groups in Idaho and throughout the [[Northwestern United States|Northwest]].Report to the Board of Regents, April 2013 (unpublished). As UI president, Nellis was a member of the [[Bowl Championship Series|BCS]] Presidential Oversight Committee.{{cite news |title=Idaho president Duane Nellis on college football playoff |first=Andy |last=Staples |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2012/writers/andy_staples/03/08/idaho-nellis-playoff/index.html |newspaper=[[Sports Illustrated]] |date=8 March 2012 |accessdate=2 March 2013}} As a nationally recognized higher education leader, he has served as a commissioner for the Northwest Commission of Colleges and Universities (one of 8 nationally recognized accreditation bodies).{{cite web |url=http://www.nwccu.org/About/Commissioners/NWCCU%20Commissioners.htm |title=Commissioners |publisher=[[NWCCU]] |accessdate=12 March 2013}} He also served as a Governor-appointed commissioner of the Western Interstate Commission for Higher Education, which coordinates higher education efforts for the 15 western states, and has been involved in various national committees for the [[Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities]] (APLU).{{cite web |url=http://www.wiche.edu/newscap/14399 |title=New Commissioners |publisher=[[WICHE]] |accessdate=12 March 2013}} ===Texas Tech University=== Nellis was announced as the sole finalist for the presidency of [[Texas Tech University]] on March 1, 2013.{{cite news |title=Duane Nellis named sole finalist for Texas Tech presidency |first=Brittany |last=Hoover |url=http://lubbockonline.com/education/2013-03-01/duane-nellis-named-sole-finalist-texas-tech-presidency |newspaper=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]] |date=1 March 2013 |accessdate=2 March 2013}} According to news reports, he was recruited for the position, and had not applied.{{cite news |title=Nellis moseying to Texas Tech |first=Brandon |last=Macz |url=http://dnews.com/local/article_ae12df30-3d96-579d-9c5c-8140d555a716.html |newspaper=[[Moscow-Pullman Daily News]] |date=2 March 2013 |accessdate=2 March 2013}} On March 22, the Texas Tech Board of Regents unanimously confirmed him as the university's next president, starting June 15.{{cite news |title=M. Duane Nellis officially named next Texas Tech president |first=Brittany |last=Hoover |url=http://lubbockonline.com/education/2013-03-22/m-duane-nellis-officially-named-next-texas-tech-president |newspaper=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]] |date=22 March 2013 |accessdate=25 March 2013}} During his presidency in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], Nellis promoted moving Texas Tech University forward toward higher levels of national prominence as a major public research university. He has advocated for continued quality enrollment growth (including stronger advocacy for national and international student recognition), accelerated research expenditures and faculty recognitions, creating a more engaged institution while promoting industry and community partnerships, with a commitment toward global connections and creativity while seeking external revenue sources to invest in the university enterprise.{{cite web |url=http://today.ttu.edu/2013/12/inauguration-celebrates-president-nellis-texas-tech-future/ |title=Inauguration Celebrates President Nellis, Texas Tech Future |publisher=Texas Tech Today |accessdate= 3 January 2014}} Under Nellis' leadership, Texas Tech was named in 2014 an APLU Innovation and Economic Prosperity University. Texas Tech also achieved Tier One Carnegie Designation for the highest research category at the conclusion of his presidential term.{{Cite news|url = http://today.ttu.edu/posts/2016/02/tier-one-carnegie-designation|title = Texas Tech achieves Tier One Carnegie Designation|last = Cook|first = Chris|date = February 2, 2016|work = Texas Tech Today|access-date = February 15, 2016|via = }} Following a candidacy for the presidency at the [[University of Wyoming]] in [[Laramie, Wyoming|Laramie]], during which he expressed frustration about Texas Tech's governance structure, Nellis announced his resignation from the Texas Tech presidency on January 8, 2016.{{cite web|last1=Watkins|first1=Mathew|title=Texas Tech University President Duane Nellis Stepping Down|url=http://www.texastribune.org/2016/01/08/texas-tech-university-president-duane-nellis-stepp/|publisher=Texas Tribune|accessdate=8 January 2016}} The university later announced that he would continue on as a tenured university honors professor and work on university strategic initiatives. From {{nowrap|2014–2017,}} Nellis was a trustee of the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges. === Ohio University === In 2017, Nellis was announced as the next president of [[Ohio University]] on February 22,{{cite news |title= Former Texas Tech president named to lead Ohio University|url=http://www.dispatch.com/news/20170222/former-texas-tech-president-named-to-lead-ohio-university}} and his presidency began on June 12 in [[Athens, Ohio|Athens]]. ==Awards and honors== *Leadership Award, Dialogue Institute *Alumni Award of Excellence, University of Idaho *Honorary Alumni Award, University of Idaho *Fellow, American Association for the Advancement of Science *Fellow, Explorers Club, New York City *Distinguished Mentor Award, National Council for Geographic Education *Fellow, Royal Geographic Society *Young Research Scholar Award, Institute of British Geographers *Distinguished Alumni Fellow, Oregon State University *Distinguished Alumnus Award, Department of Geosciences, Oregon State University *Outstanding Teaching Award, Kansas State University *University Advisor of the Year Award, Kansas State University *Gilbert Grosvenor Geographic Education National Honors, Association of American Geographers *John Fraser Hart Award for Excellence in Research, Association of American Geographers *Outstanding Contributions Award in Remote Sensing, Association of American Geographers *[[Phi Beta Kappa]], [[Golden Key International Honour Society|Golden Key]], [[Pi Kappa Phi]], [[Sigma Xi]], [[Mortar Board]], [[Gamma Theta Upsilon]] *President (2002-2003), Association of American Geographers *President (1994), National Council for Geographic Education *President, (1999-2000) Gamma Theta Upsilon (International Geographic Honor Society) *Mortar Board, Forum Chapter, inducted as member March 2015 ==Personal life== Nellis met his wife Ruthie as an undergraduate at Montana State. She was from [[Pennsylvania]]{{cite news|url=http://lubbockonline.com/education/2013-07-20/nellis-settles-life-tech#.UrGkDK-A2M8 | newspaper = Lubbock Avalanche-Journal |last=Ursch |first=Blake |title=Nellis settles in to life at Tech |date=July 20, 2013 |accessdate=December 18, 2013}} and became a [[librarian]]. As a librarian, she oversaw a science library at Kansas State, and the medical school library at West Virginia. She also worked in Kansas State's commercialization initiative, and was project manager on several major library building projects at West Virginia. Married in 1975, the couple has two sons, Jonathan and Jason. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://www.ohio.edu/president/meet-president-nellis.cfm Ohio University] – M. Duane Nellis *[http://www.geosciences.ttu.edu/people/nellis.php Texas Tech University] – M. Duane Nellis {{Ohio University}} {{Texas Tech University presidents}} {{University of Idaho presidents}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nellis, Duane}} [[Category:American geographers]] [[Category:Kansas State University faculty]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Montana State University alumni]] [[Category:Oregon State University alumni]] [[Category:People from Moscow, Idaho]] [[Category:People from Spokane, Washington]] [[Category:University of Idaho faculty]] [[Category:West Virginia University faculty]] [[Category:Presidents of Texas Tech University]] [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Presidents of the University of Idaho]] [[Category:Presidents of the American Association of Geographers]] [[Category:People from Libby, Montana]]
